Situation1: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: The city newsletter includes a short survey about bus routes open through next week.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, phone pressed to my ear as I coordinated with the contractor about the delivery of steel beams. The project was already behind schedule, and every minute counted. My inbox pinged—a reminder from the city about the public survey on bus routes. As a citizen, I always prided myself on being engaged, giving feedback to help shape our community. But the survey would take time, and I needed to review the site plans before the afternoon meeting. My mind raced: if I ignored the survey, I’d be neglecting my civic duty, but if I paused my work, the project might slip further behind. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my attention, each important in its own way. I stared at the blinking cursor, torn between the responsibilities of my profession and my commitment to my city, feeling the tension rise as the minutes ticked by.
